Effect of metal elements doping on the CePO4 catalysts for selective catalytic reduction of NO with NH3 Ran Zhao Writing – review & editing Software Investigation Writing – original draft a ⁎ Ran Pang Validation Formal analysis Supervision Data curation b Ying Wang Conceptualization Methodology c Zengwu Zhao a ⁎ a School of Materials and Metallurgy, Inner Mongolia University of Science and Technology, Baotou, Inner Mongolia 014000, China School of Materials and Metallurgy Inner Mongolia University of Science and Technology Baotou Inner Mongolia 014000 China aSchool of Materials and Metallurgy, Inner Mongolia University of Science and Technology, Baotou, Inner Mongolia 014000, China b National Key Laboratory of Rare Earth Resources Utilization, Changchun Institute of Applied Chemistry Chinese Academy of Sciences, Changchun 130022,China National Key Laboratory of Rare Earth Resources Utilization Changchun Institute of Applied Chemistry Chinese Academy of Sciences Changchun 130022 China bNational Key Laboratory of Rare Earth Resources Utilization, Changchun Institute of Applied Chemistry Chinese Academy of Sciences, Changchun 130022,China c College of Environment and Energy, Inner Mongolia University of Science and Technology, Baotou, Inner Mongolia 014000, China College of Environment and Energy Inner Mongolia University of Science and Technology Baotou Inner Mongolia 014000 China cCollege of Environment and Energy, Inner Mongolia University of Science and Technology, Baotou, Inner Mongolia 014000, China ⁎ Corresponding authors. A series of Metals doped M-CePO4 (M=Zr, Co, Mo, Cu) catalysts were prepared via the coprecipitation method for selective catalytic reduction of NO with NH3 (NH3-SCR). The results showed that the NOx conversion of M-CePO4 were higher than that of CePO4, especially the Mo-CePO4 catalysts exhibited the best low-temperature activity and N2 selectivity, the Mo-CePO4 catalysts can reach about 99% at 300 °C and excellent 70 h long stability with the coexistence of SO2 and H2O. The effect of metal elements doping on physiochemical properties of catalysts were characterized by XRD, BET, Raman, TEM, XPS, H2-TPR and NH3-TPD. SEM and TEM analysis. The results showed that part of M ions doped into CePO4 lattice resulted in lattice shrinkage. More importantly, the MOx species could not only increased the relative content of Ce3+ and surface adsorption oxygen (O′) of M-CePO4 catalysts, but also increased the specific surface area of the catalysts. It could provide more reaction sites for active gas to promote the activation of NH3 and enhance oxidation–reduction performance. The in-situ DRIFTS results suggested that NH3 were adsorbed on both Lewis and Bronsted acid sites which can easily react with NO x gas. The NO species were adsorbed on Mo-CePO4 in the form of bidentate nitrate. The main reactants of Mo-CePO4 catalysts were NH3 linked to Lewis acid sites and bidentate nitrate species on the catalytic surface. The Eley–Rideal and Langmuir–Hinshelwood mechanisms coexisted in the SCR reaction route. Graphical abstract According to the characterization results of the catalysts, the mechanism of Mo promoting the activity of NH3-SCR at low temperature was proposed (Fig. 13.). NH3 binds to Lewis acid centers, and NH4+ adsorbs on Brønsted acid centers, monotone nitrates and bidentate nitrates. Studies had shown that NH2 is an important medium in the reaction of NO (gas phase) to produce NH2NO and then decompose into N2 and H2O. As shown in Fig. 12(a), the reaction of NH3-SCR on the catalyst follows the Eley-Rideal (E-R) mechanism. The NH3 Lewis acid sites and NH4+ acid sites adsorbed on Brønsted react with NO (gas phase). As shown in Fig. 12(b), monodentate and bidentate nitrates reacted with adsorbed NH3 species, following the Langmuir-Hinshelwood (L-H) mechanism [51]. The Mo6+/Mo5+ and Ce4+/Ce3+ redox cycles on the catalyst surface participate in the whole process of the catalytic reaction. At this stage, the electron transfer process promoted the conversion of oxygen vacancy and unsaturated chemical bond, thus enhancing the adsorption activation capacity of NO and NH3, promoting the decomposition of NO molecule, and improving the catalytic performance. The –NH2 s species were intermediate adsorbed and reacted with the activated nitrate, eventually becoming N2. In the process of NO reduction, NH3 showed selectivity to the reaction intermediates, preferentially reacted with monotone nitrate and bidentate nitrate. Image, graphical abstract Keywords CePO4 NH3-SCR Solid solution DRIFTS Reaction mechanism Data availability The authors do not have permission to share data. 1 Introduction Environmental pollution is a major problem faced by humans currently. Nitrogen oxides are one of the main pollutants emitted fuel combustion and vehicle exhaust, especially the pollution of nitrogen oxides (NO, NO2, N2O), which can not only cause health problems such as bronchitis and emphysema, but also lead to photochemical smog, stratospheric ozone depletion, and acid rain [1–3]. At present, the selective catalytic reduction with NH3 (NH3-SCR) technology is the most feasible and effective strategy for reducing NOx emissions, and the catalyst is the most important component in the SCR system [4]. Currently, the V2O5-WO3 (MoO3)/TiO2 catalysts are widely used in industry [5]. However, the practical application of these V-based catalyst is limited due to the narrow operation temperature window and toxicity of vanadium species. Moreover, the H2O and SO2 in the exhaust gas can easily poison the catalysts [6,7]. Therefore, it would be the focus of future research to develop a green and efficient NH3-SCR catalyst. Studies indicated that the SCR activity of transition metal oxide catalysts (including ZrO x , CuO x ,WO x , MnO x and CoO x -based catalysts) strongly depended on the oxidation state of the metal oxide, the preparation method, and the surface oxygen species [8–10]. For example, researchers reported that the active components Fe oxides were supported on the surface of CeO2 catalysts with nano polyhedral morphology (CeO2 NPs) by impregnation method, which improved the catalytic performance of CeO2 NPs catalysts. When Fe and Mn were double-loaded, the catalysts have the best denitration(de-NO x ) performance, and the NOx conversion of the catalysts were the highest at 200 °C, which was about 98%. A series of research results demonstrated that the Fe-Mn-Ce catalyst had well redox characteristics and NH3 adsorption characteristics. Compared with the single-supported metal Fe and Mn oxide catalysts, the surface adsorbed oxygen and Ce3+ content both occupied the highest proportions, indicating that Fe-Mn-Ce catalyst has the most oxygen vacancies, which further improved the catalytic activity. In addition, Fe-Mn-Ce catalysts had good SO2 tolerance. In general, the simultaneous loading of Mn and Fe oxides on CeO2 NPs catalysts can effectively improve the low-temperature SCR performance of the catalysts [11]. Zhu [12] synthesized and characterized MoO3/CeO2 and M x O y /MoO3/CeO2 (M = Fe, Cu, Ni) catalysts. The results showed that the addition of Ni, Cu, and Fe oxides to the MoO3/CeO2 catalyst results in different structures of molybdenum species on the catalyst surface, namely isolated regular tetrahedral, highly twisted tetrahedral, and aggregated octahedral molybdenum species. For M x O y /MoO3/CeO2 (M = Fe, Cu, Ni) catalysts, the surface acid strength site of Lewis acid is affected by the surface structure of molybdenum. The de-NO x activity of the catalyst was closely related to the type and number of acid sites on the catalyst surface (whether Bronsted acid site or Lewis acid site): at low temperature, weak Lewis acid sites were the main active sites for "NO + NH3 + O2″ reaction; in the mid-temperature range, the Bronsted acid sites were the main active site; while at high temperature, the strong Lewis acid sites and the Bronsted acid sites could promote the reaction simultaneously. Phosphate has good thermal stability and suitable acid strength, which was beneficial to the improvement of NH3-SCR de-NO x performance [13,14]. A series of modified catalysts were prepared by impregnating CeO2 with H3PO4 solution, and then the de-NO x performance of the catalysts was evaluated [15]. The results showed that the NO conversion of H3PO4‐CeO2 catalyst was above 80% in the temperature range of 250−550 °C. The increase in Brønsted acidity and the enhanced redox performance of CeO2 after H3PO4 modification were the reasons for the improved de-NO x performance of the catalyst. Zeng [16] successfully synthesized a new Fe-doped CePO4 catalyst by a simple coprecipitation. The NH3 capacities of the catalysts was found to be controlled by the P sites and depended on their specific surface area. Interestingly, the Lewis acid moiety of NH3 adsorbed in the catalyst is not Fe, but it can promote the activation of NH3. More importantly, the doping of Fe3+ can induce redox equilibrium and significantly improve the redox performance of CePO4 catalysts. Finally, the reaction mechanism of the NH3-SCR reaction on the catalyst was E-R mechanism. In view of the oxygen-rich active species of transition metal oxides, the transition metal oxides can be combined with CePO4 catalysts to obtain NH3-SCR catalyst with high activity. The M (M=Zr,Co,Mo,Cu)-CePO4 were prepared by the coprecipitation method, the physicochemical properties and catalyst activity of M-CePO4 catalysts were studied by a series of measurement methods. The key species of reactive oxygen species and nitrate were determined by a series of tests such as XPS and in situ diffuse reflectance infrared spectroscopy (DRIFT). Based on the results, the possible reaction mechanism of NH3-SCR was proposed. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation M (M=Zr,Co,Mo,Cu)-doped CePO4 catalysts were prepared by the coprecipitation method. During the preparation, the desired quantities of the salt precursor (Zr (NO3)4, Co (NO3)2, (NH4)2MoO4, Cu (NO3)2) and cerium nitrate hexahydrate were dissolved in deionized water, respectively. After stirring for 30 min, H3PO4 solution (molar ratio of n(Ce+M)/nP = 1) was added in stoichiometric proportion with the molar ratio of M/Ce in the catalyst being 0.35. Then, the mixture solution pH was adjusted to 5 by ammonia. Subsequently, the mixture was then stirred vigorously for 2 h and aged at room temperature for 24 h.The mixture was separated and washed four times, dried in an 100 °C oven, and calcined at 500 °C for 3 h to obtain the desired catalysts. For brevity, the M-doped CePO4 for different elements were designated as Zr-CePO4, Co-CePO4, Mo-CePO4, and Cu-CePO4. The CePO4 was prepared according to the method described above. 2.2 Catalytic activity evaluation The catalytic performance of these catalysts for the NH3-SCR reaction was determined under a continuous-flow fixed-bed quartz tube microreactor (diameter 20 mm) at 100−450 °C under atmospheric pressure. The mass of the catalyst sample in the quartz tube was 0.6 g, the total flow rate of the gas in the reaction device was 100 mL/min, and the introduced gas mixture comprised 500 ppm NO, 500 ppm NH3, 6 vol% O2, and N2 as the balance. When the reaction spatial speed reached 30,000 h − 1, and the GASMET-DX4000 model Fourier infrared spectroscopy flue gas analyzer from Finland was measured by the inlet and export concentration of the flue gas composition online, each temperature interval (100−450 °C, every 50°) held for 15 min. The calculation formula for NO conversion and N2 selectivity is as follows: (1) NO conversion ( % ) = ( [ NO ] in − [ NO ] out ) / [ NO ] in × 100 % (2) N 2 selectivity ( % ) = [ N O ] in + [ N H 3 ] i n − [ N O 2 ] o u t − 2 [ N 2 O ] o u t − [ N O ] o u t − [ N H 3 ] o u t [ N O ] in + [ N H 3 ] i n − [ N O ] o u t − [ N H 3 ] o u t × 100 % 2.3 Catalyst characterization X-ray powder diffraction (XRD) was determined on the D8 Advanced diffractometer with Cu Kα radiation (Bruker, German) at an angle of 2θ ranged from 10 to 80° The principle is to use X-ray diffraction, and the diffraction effect of the metal compound crystal in the catalytic material is subjected to a substance structure analysis. The crystallite size (D) of the catalyst was calculated by the Scherrer formula: (3) D = K λ / β cos θ In the formula, D is the crystallite size, K is Scherrer constant, λ is the X-ray wavelength, and β is a diffraction peak halfway, θ is a diffraction angle. Raman spectra of these catalysts were recorded on the INVIA (Renishaw, England) Laser Raman spectrometer. The excitation wavelength was 514 nm with Ar+ laser beam. High-resolution transmission electron microscope (HRTEM, JEOL JEM2100, 100 kV) was used to observe the surface morphology and structure of the calcined powders. The Brunauer-Emmett-Teller characterization was performed using automated specific surface and aperture analyzer (BeiShiDe, China). The prepared sample is loaded into the sample tube, accounting for about one-half of the bottom. Prior to adsorption was measured, the sample was vacuumed by vacuum at 200 °C. Saturated vapor pressure 1.0209 bar, N2 is the adhesion and the adsorption temperature are 77.3 K. X-ray photoelectron spectra (XPS) of these catalysts were collected on a surface analysis system (ESCALAB 250Xi, Thermo Fisher Scientific) with monochromatic Al Kα radiation (1486.6 eV). By measuring the inner layer electron binding energy, the valence change of the metal ion type and the active component in the catalytic material can be analyzed, and the oxidative performance analysis of the catalyst is provided. Both temperature-programmed desorption (TPD) and temperature-programmed reduction (TPR) were performed on the chemical adsorption instrument (PCA-1200, China) with a thermal conductivity detector. Prior to the TPD experiments, the samples (0.2 g) were pre-treated at 200 °C in a flow of pure N2 for 30 min, followed by NH3/N2 adsorption at 100 °C for 1 h. Finally, the temperature was raised to 500 °C in the flowing N2 at 10 °C/min. For H2-TPR, the samples were reduced by increasing the temperature from 50−800 °C at 10 °C/min. In situ diffuse reflectance infrared spectroscopy (DRIFT) was performed using the Nicolet IZ10 Fourier transform infrared (FTIR) spectrometer. The typical reactant gas composition was as follows: 500 ppm NO, 500 ppm NH3, 6vol% O2, and N2 as the balance gas with a flow rate of 100 mL /min. During the experiment, catalysts were pre-treated at 200 °C for 40 min and then cooled to room temperature to collect the background spectrum. Afterwards, various experiments were conducted. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalytic performance evaluation Fig. 1 showed the NH3-SCR catalytic activities and N2 selectivity of doped metal M (M=Zr, Co, Mo, Cu)-CePO4 catalysts, respectively. It can be seen from Fig. 1(a) that in the whole temperature range (100−450 °C), the NO x conversion of M (M= Zr, Co, Mo, Cu)-CePO4 improved the catalytic activities compared with pure CePO4 catalyst. However, the catalytic activity of Co-CePO4 was higher than that of pure CePO4 at low temperature, but decreased sharply at medium and high temperature (>300 °C). Mo-CePO4 catalysts had the highest NO x conversion, which reached 97.8% at 300 °C, the NO x conversion of Co-CePO4 attained 90.8% at 300 °C then rapidly decreased to 81% as the temperature increased to 400 °C. The catalytic activity followed the order: Mo-CePO4> Zr-CePO4> Cu-Ce PO4> Co-Ce PO4> CePO4. According to the above results, it can be concluded that M (M=Zr, Mo, Cu,Co)-CePO4 can significantly improve the catalytic activity of CePO4 [17]. Fig. 1(b) showed the N2 selectivity of the catalysts, all of which maintained a high N2 selectivity of more than 80% at test temperatures ranging from 100 to 450 °C.However, The N2 selectivity of Co-CePO4 decreased sharply at 200 °C. As showed in Fig.S1, the results showed that a small amount of NH3 overoxidation occurs in the NH3-SCR reaction over Co-CePO4 catalysts. The stability and resistance to the H2O and SO2 are important for NH3-SCR catalysts. So, it was necessary to test the catalyst performances below 300 °C. As shown in Fig. 2 (a), in the absence of H2O and SO2, the Mo-CePO4, Zr-CePO4, and Cu-CePO4 catalysts all exhibited high catalytic activity and excellent thermal stability, maintaining high activity after continuous operation for 70 h. Furthermore, the four-cycle tests from 180 to 400 °Cwere carried out to investigate the effect of temperature change on catalytic activity of Mo-CePO4, there was no significant differences in NO x conversion during the possess. As presented in Fig. 2(b), when 10 vol% H2O was introduced into the reaction gas alone, the NO x conversion of the catalyst was slightly reduced, but the effect on Cu-CePO4 was greater, indicating that Mo-CePO4 and Zr-CePO4 catalysts have strong water vapor resistance. When 100 ppm of SO2 was introduced alone in the reaction gas (Fig. 2c), compared with Zr-CePO4 and Cu-CePO4, the SO2 resistance of Mo-CePO4 catalysts was significantly improved, and its NO x conversion decreased only slightly and remained above 86% throughout the test period. Notably, the NH3-SCR activity of Mo-CePO4 recovered to 92.6% after SO2 was turned off. When SO2 and H2O were added to the reaction gas at the same time (Fig. 2d), the NO x conversion of Mo-CePO4 catalyst decreased from 94.9% to 89.9% compared with Zr-CePO4 and Cu-CePO4 catalysts, indicating that the SO2 and H2O resistance. Furthermore, when SO2 and H2O flow were turned off, the NO x conversion on Mo-CePO4 catalysts also recovered gradually, while Zr-CePO4 and Cu-CePO4 catalysts recovered only slightly. These results confirm that Mo plays a key role in enhancing the H2O and SO2 resistance of the catalysts. 3.2 XRD,Raman and Hrtem results Fig. 3 (a) presented the XRD patterns of M (M=Zr, Co, Mo, Cu)-CePO4 catalysts. The typical diffraction peaks of all samples centered at 14.5°, 20.0°, 25.2°, 28.8°, 31.7°, 41.5° and 48.5° correspond to (100) (101) (110) (111) (102) (211) and (212) crystal planes, respectively, which mainly exhibited the hexagonal cerium phosphate crystal (PDF 34–1380), the XRD diffraction peak position and intensity of the sample have little affected by metal ion doping. In addition to the weak offset of individual peaks, there is a good correspondence with the peak of pure CePO4. There were no diffraction peaks caused by metal oxides in the figure, which caused two reasons for this phenomenon. First, these metal oxides partially may enter the skeleton of CePO4, with the rest highly dispersed on the surface of CePO4. Another reason is that these metal oxides do not enter the crystal lattice, are small and uniformly distributed, which exceeds the detection limit of XRD technology [13]. Fig. 3(b) is a diffraction peak near 26−34°, in a doped four sets of images, their lattice parameters and crystallite size (D) were also calculated by Scherer equation and summarized in Table 1. The diffraction peak of the M (M=Zr, Co, Mo, Cu)-CePO4 catalysts shifted to higher angles,the radius of Zr4+, Co3+, Mo6+ and Cu2+ ions are 0.72 Å, 0.61 Å, 0.59 Å and 0. 70 Å and smaller than Ce3+ (1.02 Å), and doping Mn+ in CePO4 crystal lattice will inevitably lead to its lattice shrinkage, thus reducing the lattice parameters of M (M=Zr, Co, Mo, Cu)-CePO4 catalysts [18]. The crystal plane of CePO4 (111) was selected to measure the crystallite size of the catalysts. The crystallite size of pure CePO4 was 10.6 nm, with the introduction of M n +, the crystallite size of M-CePO4 catalyst is as follows: Co-CePO4>Cu-CePO4>Mo-CePO4>Zr-CePO4, indicating that doping transition metal element was significantly cause lattice shrinkage. The diffraction peaks of Mo-CePO4 and Zr-CePO4 obviously become weaker and broader, therefore, the grain size of Zr-CePO4 and Mo-CePO4 were significantly minimized, indicating that the doped Mo and Zr rear grains were further refined. These results showed that these transition metal oxides were partially doped into CePO4 lattices, SEM mapping in Fig. S2 showed that MoO x were highly dispersed on the CePO4 catalyst surface. These results indicated that part of Mn+ were doped into the CePO4 lattice, and part of MO x were highly dispersed with the catalyst surface. Raman analysis is a good characterization for the nano-sized materials. Raman spectra is an efficient technique to characterize the oxygen vacancies [19]. As shown in Fig. 4 , Several frequency bands caused by P-O can be observed, belonging to symmetric bending vibration (400−500 cm−1), asymmetric bending vibration (530−650 cm−1), symmetric stretching vibration (950−1000 cm−1) and asymmetric stretching vibration peak (1050−1150 cm−1) [20]. The sharp peak ascribed to the F2g vibration band (located at 464 cm−1) of CeO2 [21]. These results indicated that the Ce species slightly existed in the form of CeO2, which is highly separated on the catalyst surface, consistent with the XRD results. In addition, only vibrational peaks of CePO4 were observed in M (M=Zr, Co, Mo, Cu)-CePO4 catalysts, and no additional peaks belonging to metal oxides were observed, which was consistent with the results of XRD. The weak peak around 615 cm−1 was attributed to the vibrational peak caused by the oxygen vacancies [22–24]. Furthermore, the intensity ratio between 615 cm−1 and 962 cm−1 (i.e., I615/I962) is proportional to the concentration of oxygen vacancy in the materials. Therefore, we calculated the values of I615/I962 and half band width for these samples, listed in Table 3. The I615/I962 values for the Zr-CePO4 catalyst (i.e., 0.14) was close to that of the CePO4 catalyst (i.e., 0.12), while remarkably increasing for Co-CePO4, Mo-CePO4 and Cu-CePO4 catalysts (i.e., 0.18, 0.21 and 0.31) due to the strong interaction among Co, Mo, Cu, and CePO4. Oxygen vacancies help in the redox cycle and form more acid sites on the catalytic surface [25], making it one of the main reasons for the excellent activity of these catalysts. The crystal lattice symmetry affects the changes in peak width [21]. The lower the symmetry, the broader the Raman peak [21]. As shown in Table 3, the vibration peaks ascribed to P-O and Ce-O of the M (M=Zr, Co, Mo, Cu)-CePO4 catalysts were clearly broadened than those of the pure CePO4 indicating the lower crystal lattice symmetry of these catalysts. Therefore, the broadening of the peak suggested that these transition metals were more likely to be partially doped into the CePO4 lattice, consistent with the XRD results. TEM characterizations can provide the direct evidence of the catalyst's physical structure information. As shown in Fig. 5 a, CePO4 presented a nanorod shape with 5 − 10 nm diameter and 20−100 nm length. After doping with M (M=Zr, Co, Mo, Cu), the catalysts (Fig. 5b–e) presented a nanorod shape like those of CePO4. However, the diameter and length reduced. These results indicate that the M (M=Zr, Co, Mo, Cu)-CePO4 changed the morphology. For CePO4 catalyst (Fig. 5f), the lattice fringes were around 0.6172 nm distant, ascribed to the monazite CePO4(1 0 0) facets (PDF 34–1380). As shown in Fig. 5g–j, the TEM results suggested that the lattice spacing of the M (M=Zr, Co, Mo, Cu)-CePO4 catalysts reduced with respect to the pure CePO4. This is because the ionic radii of Mn+ were smaller than the ionic radius of Ce3+(1.02 Å). It indicated that partial Mn+ incorporation into the CePO4 lattice led to the lattice shrinkage, thus confirming the doping of the partial transition metals into the CePO4 lattice [7]. 3.3 BET analyses Fig. 6 is the N2 adsorption-desorption isotherm and pore size distribution of M (M = Zr, Co, Mo, Cu)-CePO4 catalysts, and Table 2 lists the BET surface area, pore size and pore volume of different catalysts. All five catalysts produced type IV isotherms and H3 hysteresis rings, which means that many mesopores (2 − 50 nm) exist in them (Fig. 6a) [7]. In addition, according to the corresponding pore size distribution curve (Fig. 6b), most of the pores of CePO4, Zr-CePO4 and Co-CePO4 are concentrated in 2 − 6 nm, and the pores of Mo-CePO4 catalyst are concentrated in 4 − 8 nm, the dominant pore size distribution more uniformly, the pores of the Cu-CePO4 catalyst are concentrated at 4 nm, indicating that there are abundant mesoporous pores in the material. From the BET analysis in Table 2, the specific surface area of CePO4 is 53.1m2/g. After doping with M (M=Zr, Co, Mo, Cu), the specific surface area of the catalyst is improved, and the Mo-CePO4 catalyst is 95.9m2/g. The specific surface area of M (M=Zr, Co, Mo, Cu)-CePO4 increases, which may be due to the decrease of the crystal size after doping with transition metal ions, resulting in the increase of the specific surface area. 3.4 XPS analysis The XPS spectra of Ce 3d, O 1 s, P 2p, and Mo 3d for catalysts are depicted in Fig. 7 (a–d), respectively. Meanwhile, the XPS data of the catalysts were evaluated with the results shown in Table 4 . From Fig. 7(a), Ce 3d could be fitted by eight bands. Among them, the peaks at v'(885.45 eV) and u'(904.05 eV) represented the Ce3+, while the others represented Ce4+ [26]. Generally, the area ratio between the Ce3+ bands and the ten bands can reflect the Ce3+ ratio on the sample surface [24]. It shows that the ratios of Ce3+ over M (M=Zr, Co, Mo, Cu)-CePO4 catalysts were all higher than that over CePO4 (i.e., 40.0%), and Mo-CePO4 catalyst (i.e., 53.6%) exhibited an obvious increase in the Ce3+ ratio compared to other catalysts. These results indicate that the addition of M enhances the interaction with Ce, which may lead to the formation of more oxygen vacancies in the low state of Ce. Oxygen vacancies are usually generated by electron transfer between Ce3+ and Ce4+, and a higher proportion of Ce3+ promotes not only conducive to oxygen deprivation, but also affect the redox cycle of SCR reaction. This may help to explain the higher NO x activation of M-CePO4 [27]. As shown in Fig. 7(b), there are four oxygen species in the sample, and the peak of O' centered on 533.3 eV is attributed to surface adsorption oxygen, the peak O'' at 532.5–533.0 eV is caused by bridge oxygen (P-O-P), the peak O''' at 530.7–531.8 eV is attributed to non-bridging oxygen (P-O) and the peak O'"' at 529.0 − 530.0 eV is attributed to lattice oxygen of CeO2 [16]. As the most active oxygen and surface adsorption of the NH3-SCR reaction, the surface adsorption of oxygen can accelerate NO to nitrogen oxide, and promote the NH3-SCR reaction through the "fast SCR" pathway: NO+NO2+2NH3=2N2+3H2O. It is well known that this pathway plays a key role in the low temperature SCR reaction [28]. It can be seen from Table 4 that the surface adsorption of Mo-CePO4 is 24.9%, higher than pure CePO4 (22.4%) and other elements doped CePO4 catalysts. It is confirmed that the interaction between Mo and CePO4 does affect the oxygen storage capacity of the catalysts [29, 30]. At the same time, the position of O′′, O′″ and O′″′ are shifted to high binding energy, indicating that the interaction of oxygen atoms and Mn+ results in a higher oxidation state. Therefore, the activity of the catalyst is closely related to the Ce3+ content. The P 2p XPS species of the catalysts are shown in Fig. 7(c). Mn+ (Mn+ = Zr4+, Mo6+, and Cu2+) served as an electron absorbing group, the electron cloud density around P was changed by doping induced M-O-P bond [14]. Compared with CePO4, the binding energies of P 2p for the samples doped with M (M=Zr, Mo, Cu) were shifted to higher positions (Table 4). Furthermore, the charges on Ce 3d and O 1 s ions were significantly affected by their surrounding chemical environment, as the peak shifts depend on the properties of the dopant ions [13]. The Mo 3d XPS species for the Mo-CePO4 are illustrated in Fig. 7(d). Mo 3d could be fitted by two bands. Among them, the peaks at 232.6 and 236.3 eV all represented the Mo6+ ions [31,32]. According to reports, Mo6+ species are active sites for epoxidation reactions. The doped Mo element was Mo6+, which can enhance the electron transfer of the catalysts and facilitate the formation of oxygen vacancies and unsaturated chemical bonds, thus improving the catalytic activity. 3.5 H2-TPR and NH3-TPD The H2-TPR curves of the catalysts were shown in Fig. 8 . In the CePO4 spectrum, only a small H2 consumption peak appears at 480 °C, which may be due to the reduction of surface and bulk Ce4+ species [25,33]. The incorporation of M led to an apparent shift towards lower temperatures for the reduction peaks of CePO4, indicating that the introduction of metal oxides can significantly improve the redox performance of the catalyst. Mo-CePO4 displayed the lowest reduction temperature (340 °C). The peak at 340 °C was attributed to the reduction of surface oxygen species [32]. The peak at 559 °C was attributed to the reaction of Mo species with CePO4, resulting the reduction of Ce4+ on the surface. The Cu-CePO4 catalyst showed the wide reduction peak at about 396−500 °C can be attributed to the interaction between surface CuO x species and CePO4[13]. No characteristic peak of CoO x and ZrO x was found in Co-CePO4 and Zr-CePO4 catalysts, and the peak at 434 °C and 396 °C were all attributed to the reduction of bulk phase Ce4+ to Ce3+ [30]. It is generally believed that the area of H2 consumption peak positively affects the amount of reducible material in the catalysts. Fig. 8b shows the area comparison of hydrogen consumption of each catalyst, followed the order:Mo-CePO4 > Zr-CePO4 > Cu-CePO4> Co-CePO4>CePO4 (The peak areas were 4712, 3904,2738,1000, and 268, respectively), indicating that M-CePO4 had more active sites and was more conducive to adsorption and reaction, thus greatly improving the catalytic activity of M-CePO4. The surface acidity of the catalyst will affect the adsorption of NH3, therefore affecting the process of catalytic reaction. Fig. 9 displays the NH3-TPD profiles of the catalysts. All catalysts had a broad overlapping peak of NH3 desorption (50−600 °C). All catalysts exhibited NH3 desorption peaks which like CePO4, which was caused by NH3 desorption from the acidic site of CePO4. These peaks were due to the desorption of to NH3 from the acid site of CePO4 rather than the metal oxide. These results suggest that CePO4 may act as an acid site in the adsorption and activation of NH3. Fig. 9 showed that all samples are divided into three peaks by Gaussian fitting depending on different acid sites The desorption peak centered at 200 °C ascribed to weak Bronsted acid sites(peak α), the desorption peak centered at 300 °C could be ascribed to the strong Bronsted acid sites and medium Lewis acid sites(peak β), and the desorption peak located at higher temperature (>350 °C) was ascribed to NH3 bound to strong Lewis acid sites (peak γ) (Fig. 9 and Table 5 ) [7,30]. CePO4 catalyst consists of weak,medium and strong acid sites. With the addition of M, the acid content of M-CePO4 catalysts increased significantly, these results indicate that there is a strong interaction between M and Ce, especially Mo-CePO4 and Cu-CePO4 catalysts. The number of weak and medium strong acid sites is significantly increased. Integrating the desorption peaks of catalysts showed that the NH3 adsorption capacity followed the order: Mo-CePO4 > Zr-CePO4 > Cu-CePO4≈Co-CePO4>CePO4 (the peak areas were 2593.7, 2200.4,2155, 2139.5, and 1701.6, respectively). Mo-CePO4 catalysts had the highest NH3 capacity and relatively better NH3 activation capacity, the enhanced redox performance and NH3 desorption performance may be the main factors for the superior NH3-SCR activity of the Mo-CePO4 catalysts. 3.6 In situ drifts results 3.6.1 Surface adsorption state Fig. 10 (a) shows an in-situ infrared spectral map of the NH3 adsorption by the Mo-CePO4 at 350 °C. With the introduction of NH3, a series of adsorption peaks appeared on the surface. Among them, the adsorption peaks centered at 1442 and 1753 cm−1 belonged to NH4 + on the Brønsted acid sites [34]. The vibrational adsorption peaks at 1355 cm−1 were associated with the NH2 species [35]. The adsorption peaks were centered at 1240 and 1582 cm−1, attributed to the NH3 linked to the Lewis acid site [25,36,37]. The stronger infrared absorption peak at the Lewis acid position is shown in Fig. 9, indicating that the Lewis acid site is the main NH3-adsorption acid site on the Mo-CePO4 catalyst surface, consistent with the NH3-TPD results. As the NH3 gas passage time increased, both the NH4 + / NH3 species adsorbed to the Brønsted and Lewis acid positions existed in a highly stable state, indicating that the Mo-CePO4 catalyst showed a good NH3 adsorption capacity, and the introduction of Mo provided a stronger acid position-promoting reaction on the catalyst surface, thus favoring the progress of the SCR reaction. Fig. 10(b) shows an in-situ infrared spectrogram of the NO + O2 adsorption by the Mo-CePO4 at 350 °C. With the introduction of NO + O2, a series of adsorption peaks appeared. The bands at 1284 and 1540 cm−1 belonged to the bidentate nitrate adsorption peak adsorbed to Ce and Mo [38] and remained stable over time. The band at 1413 cm−1 belonged to the monolentate nitrate adsorption peak [39] but disappeared after passing into NO + O2 for 30 min, indicating that the adsorpted bridge nitrate on the catalyst was not stable. The band at 1223 cm−1 was attributed to the vibration peak of monolentate nitrate and remained stable [40], and a new vibration peak belonging to monolentate nitrate appeared at 1382 cm−1 after introduction to NO + O2 for 20 min. Monolentate nitrate and bidentate nitrate species occupied the dominant active site and the intensity of the absorption peak of monodentate nitrate increased. The vibration peak at 1666 cm−1 belonged to the intermediate NO2 species, indicating the transformation of NO to NO2 in the adsorbed state during the catalytic de-NOx process, providing the basic conditions for the subsequent reaction of NH4 + and NO2. 3.6.2 Surface thermal stability In Fig. 11 (a), the 1240 and 1608 cm−1 peaks belonged to the NH3 of the Lewis acid site and disappeared when the temperature rose to 250 °C, indicating that the NH3 adsorbed by the Lewis acid position was unstable at low temperature, and the Lewis acid position was involved a little when the temperature was below 250 °C. As the temperature increased to 250 °C, the vibrational adsorption peak belonging to the NH3 of the Lewis acid site began at 1582, 1462 and 1208 cm−1 [41–43], indicating that the Lewis acid site was involved in the SCR reaction process throughout the temperature. Only one peak at 1724 cm−1 belonged to the NH4 + adsorbed at the Bronsted acid site, which disappeared in the high-temperature segment, followed by the new NH4 + vibration absorption peaks at 1785, 1753 and 1540 cm−1 [44,45]. The large Brønsted and Lewis acid positions in the medium to high temperature section involved in the SCR reaction, confirmed the low catalyst activity in the low-temperature section, which was consistent with the activity test results. The peak at 1380 cm−1 belonged to the vibrational peak of the adsorbed NH3 species oxidation, and the peak at 1305 cm−1 belonged to the product of the dehydrogenation reaction of the activated NH3 species-NH2 [46,47]. Fig. 11(b) shows the in-situ infrared spectrum of the NO + O2 thermal stability on the Mo-CePO4 surface. 1436 cm−1 belonged to the vibrational peak of the nitro group NO2 [32], remaining relatively stable in the whole temperature range. The peak at 1305 cm−1 belonged to the vibration peak of bidentate nitrite, which gradually increased and remained stable as the temperature increased. When the temperature rose above 300 °C, the peaks at 1550 and 1582 cm−1 belonging to bidentate nitrate appeared successively [48]. The emerging peaks at 1616 and 1666 cm−1 belonged to the bridge nitrate and NO2 species, respectively [25]. The type and amount of nitrate adsorbed on the low-temperature section of the catalyst surface were less, resulting in its low-temperature catalytic activity, consistent with the activity test results. 3.6.3 Transient reaction of NO and NH3 on catalysts To further research the reaction mechanism of NH3-SCR, the in-situ DRIFTS test was performed on Mo-CePO4 at 350 °C. NH3 was pre-adsorbed on Mo-CePO4 for 40 min, followed by N2 purging at 350 °C, then NO + O2 was introduced to investigate the reaction between adsorbed NH3 and gaseous NO + O2. With the exposure of NH3 for 40 min, the bands at 1240, 1355, 1442, 1582, and 3319 cm−1 were detected in Fig. 12 (a). The band centered at 1442 cm−1 belonged to the NH4 + on the Bronsted acid sites [49]. And the band at 1355 cm−1 was associated with the amide species (–NH2) [35]. The bands formed at 1240 and 1582 cm−1 possibly attributed to the NH3 linked to the Lewis acid sites [36,37]. The band at 3319 cm−1 was associated to the NH and HN-H vibrations of ammonia [36]. The –NH2 intermediates originating from the coordinated NH3 and NH4 + species were activated by the active sites on the catalytic surface. As the reports showed, –NH2 species was an important intermediate for the reaction of –NH2 and NO (gas-phase) to form NH2NO, and further decomposed into N2 and H2O [25]. Obviously, With the exposure of NO + O2 for 5 min, the NH3 linked to the Lewis acid sites and NH4 + on the Bronsted acid sites quickly participated in the reaction and gradually disappeared, which directly reacted with the NO species. Evidently, all the adsorbed NH3 species were participated in the NH3-SCR reactions on the catalyst indicating that NH3-SCR reaction on the Mo-CePO4 catalyst surface followed an Eley–Rideal (E–R) mechanism. Upon NO + O2 introduction, some peaks occurred due to nitrate species and grew with time. The band at 1192 cm−1 was related to the bridging nitrates [24]. The bands at 1223 and 1382 cm−1 were attributed to monodentate nitrates. Moreover, the band at 3365 cm−1 was attributed to NO2 species [50]. Fig. 12(b) showed the reaction of NH3 with pre-adsorbed NO + O2 species at 350 °C. With the exposure of NO + O2 for 40 min, the bands at 1223, 1284, 1382 1540, 1666, and 3365 cm−1 were detected. The bands at 1223 and 1382 cm−1 were attributed to monodentate nitrates. The bands at 1284 and 1540 cm−1 were assigned to bidentate nitrates. The bands at 1666 and 3365 cm−1 were attributed to the adsorbed NO2 [50]. With the purging of NH3, these peaks gradually decreased. Another peak attributing to the NH4 + species (1442 cm−1) bounds on the Brønsted acid sites, the bands at 1240 and 1582 cm−1 associated to the NH3 linked to the Lewis acid sites emerged and grew with time [44]. The bands at 1355 and 3319 cm−1 were associated to the amide species (-NH2) and NH or HN-H vibrations of ammonia, respectively. The -NH2 intermediates appeared and intensified, possibly reacting with NO to form NH2NO, and finally decomposed into N2 and H2O. The adsorbed NOx species reacted with the adsorbed NH3 species, indicating that the NH3-SCR reaction over the Mo-CePO4 catalyst followed a Langmuir–Hinshelwood (L–H) mechanism. 3.7 Mechanism analysis According to the characterization results of the catalysts, the mechanism of Mo promoting the activity of NH3-SCR at low temperature was proposed (Fig. 13 .). NH3 binds to Lewis acid centers, and NH4+ adsorbs on Brønsted acid centers, monotone nitrates and bidentate nitrates. Studies had shown that NH2 is an important medium in the reaction of NO (gas phase) to produce NH2NO and then decompose into N2 and H2O. As shown in Fig. 12(a), the reaction of NH3-SCR on the catalyst follows the Eley-Rideal (E-R) mechanism. The NH3 Lewis acid sites and NH4+ acid sites adsorbed on Brønsted react with NO (gas phase). As shown in Fig. 12(b), monodentate and bidentate nitrates reacted with adsorbed NH3 species, following the Langmuir-Hinshelwood (L-H) mechanism [51]. The Mo6+/Mo5+ and Ce4+/Ce3+ redox cycles on the catalyst surface participate in the whole process of the catalytic reaction. At this stage, the electron transfer process promoted the conversion of oxygen vacancy and unsaturated chemical bond, thus enhancing the adsorption activation capacity of NO and NH3, promoting the decomposition of NO molecule, and improving the catalytic performance. The –NH2 s species were intermediate adsorbed and reacted with the activated nitrate, eventually becoming N2. In the process of NO reduction, NH3 showed selectivity to the reaction intermediates, preferentially reacted with monotone nitrate and bidentate nitrate. The relevant reaction equations are as follows: (4) NH3(g) → NH3(a) (Lewis acid sites) (5) NH3(g)→NH4 + (a) (Bronsted acid sites) (6) Ce3++ 1/2O2←→Ce4++O − E-R mechanism: (7) NH3(a)+O −→ -NH2+ -OH (8) NH4 + (a)←→ -NH2+2H++e − (9) -OH+H +←→H2O (10) -NH2+NO→NH2NO→N2+H2O L-H mechanism: (11) NO+O −←→ -NO2 NO+2O−←→ -NO3 (monodentate/bidentate nitrates) (12) Mo6+-NH2+ -NO2→Mo5++N2+H2O+ 1/2O2 (13) Mo6+-NH2+ -NO3→N2+H2O+O2 (14) Ce4++Mo5+←→Ce3++Mo6+ 4 Conclusions A series of metal-doped M-CePO4(M=Zr, Co, Mo, Cu) catalysts were synthesized by the co-precipitation method for low temperature NH3-SCR. The incorporation of M improved the NH3-SCR activity on the CePO4. The experimental results demonstrated that Mo-CePO4 catalyst showed the best catalytic performance more than 90% NO x conversion between 250−400 °C due to its abundant acid and NH3 binding ability and strong redox sites, the N2 selectivity of the Mo-CePO4 was exceeded 95% among all the reaction temperatures. Furthermore, the M-CePO4 (M=Co, Mo, Cu) also displayed excellent activity stability and resistance to H2O/SO2 in the long-term operation. Combined with the results of XPS, NH3-TPD, H2-TPR, the M-CePO4 can provide more active sites (Ce3+) and surface adsorption oxygen(O′) than CePO4 due to the different structures. This further confirmed that the interaction between M (M = Zr, Co, Mo, and Cu) and CePO4 could indeed affect the ability of the catalysts for oxygen storage, thus, agreeing well with the higher SCR performances in the high-temperature range. The results of in-situ DRIFTS experiments showed that NH3 adsorbed on Lewis acid and Brønsted acid of Mo-CePO4 can easily react with NO x gas. NO was adsorbed on Mo-CePO4 in the form of nitrates. In the process of NO reduction, NH3 as the reaction intermediate, and preferentially reacted with monotone nitrate and bidentate nitrate. The main reactants of Mo-CePO4 catalyst were NH3 connected to Lewis acid site and nitrates on the catalyst surface. Therefore, both E-R and l-H mechanisms existed on the catalysts. This work systematically introduces the advantages and reasons of M doped CePO4 in denitrification. Finally, the Mo-CePO4 catalysts had good water and sulfur dioxide resistance. In conclusion, the study of the reaction mechanism provides theoretical guidance for the cerium phosphate-based catalysts, indicating that it has the potential application in the future. coredata.dc:description: A series of Metals doped M-CePO4 (M=Zr, Co, Mo, Cu) catalysts were prepared via the coprecipitation method for selective catalytic reduction of NO with NH3 (NH3-SCR). The results showed that the NOx conversion of M-CePO4 were higher than that of CePO4, especially the Mo-CePO4 catalysts exhibited the best low-temperature activity and N2 selectivity, the Mo-CePO4 catalysts can reach about 99% at 300 °C and excellent 70 h long stability with the coexistence of SO2 and H2O. The effect of metal elements doping on physiochemical properties of catalysts were characterized by XRD, BET, Raman, TEM, XPS, H2-TPR and NH3-TPD. SEM and TEM analysis. The results showed that part of M ions doped into CePO4 lattice resulted in lattice shrinkage. More importantly, the MOx species could not only increased the relative content of Ce3+ and surface adsorption oxygen (O′) of M-CePO4 catalysts, but also increased the specific surface area of the catalysts. It could provide more reaction sites for active gas to promote the activation of NH3 and enhance oxidation–reduction performance. The in-situ DRIFTS results suggested that NH3 were adsorbed on both Lewis and Bronsted acid sites which can easily react with NO x gas. The NO species were adsorbed on Mo-CePO4 in the form of bidentate nitrate. The main reactants of Mo-CePO4 catalysts were NH3 linked to Lewis acid sites and bidentate nitrate species on the catalytic surface. The Eley–Rideal and Langmuir–Hinshelwood mechanisms coexisted in the SCR reaction route.
coredata.dc:title: Effect of metal elements doping on the CePO4 catalysts for selective catalytic reduction of NO with NH3
